metadata.title: Multitasking | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: This Apple Developer Documentation page provides comprehensive guidelines for implementing multitasking in apps across Apple platforms. It covers best practices for handling app switching, audio interruptions, background tasks, and platform-specific multitasking behaviors for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and visionOS.

content.text: Multitasking lets people switch quickly from one app to another, performing tasks in each.

content.description: A stylized orange icon representing multitasking. The icon shows two overlapping rounded squares - one orange square in the foreground and one darker orange/brown square in the background, positioned at a slight offset to suggest layering or multiple windows. The squares have rounded corners consistent with Apple's design language. The icon is set against a light gradient background that transitions from white to a very subtle warm tone.
content.composition: Centered icon with overlapping geometric shapes suggesting layered windows or apps
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration, Apple HIG iconography style
content.contextualRelevance: Hero image representing the multitasking concept - multiple overlapping app windows
content.altText: Multitasking icon showing two overlapping orange squares

content.text: People expect to use multitasking on their devices, and they may think something is wrong if your app doesn't allow it. With rare exceptions — such as some games, and Apple Vision Pro apps running in a Full Space — every app needs to work well with multitasking.
In addition to app switching, multitasking can present different experiences on different devices; see Platform considerations.

paragraphs.text: A great multitasking experience helps people accomplish tasks in multiple apps by managing content in a variety of simultaneous contexts. Because you don't know when people will initiate multitasking, your app or game always needs to be prepared to save and restore their context.

paragraphs.leadText: Pause activities that require people's attention or active participation when they switch away.
paragraphs.bodyText: If your app is a game or a media-viewing app, for example, make sure people don't miss anything when they switch to another app. When they switch back, let them continue as if they never left.

Occasionally, audio from another app or the system itself may interrupt your app's audio. For example, an incoming phone call or a music playlist initiated by Siri might interrupt your app's audio. When situations like these occur, people expect your app to respond in the following ways:

bulletList.text: Pause audio indefinitely for primary audio interruptions, such as playing music, podcasts, or audiobooks.
Temporarily lower the volume or pause the audio for shorter interruptions, such as GPS directional notifications, and resume the original volume or playback when the interruption ends.

additionalParagraphs.leadText: Finish user-initiated tasks in the background.
additionalParagraphs.bodyText: When someone starts a task like downloading assets or processing a video file, they expect it to finish even if they switch away from your app. If your app is in the middle of performing a task that doesn't need additional input, complete it in the background before suspending.

Your app can send notifications when it's suspended or running in the background. If people start an important or time-sensitive task in your app, and then switch away from it, they might appreciate receiving a notification when the task completes so they can switch back to your app and take the next step. In contrast, people don't generally need to know the moment a routine or secondary task completes. In this scenario, avoid sending an unnecessary notification; instead, let people check on the task when they return to your app. For guidance, see Managing notifications.

paragraphs.text: On iPhone, multitasking lets people use FaceTime or watch a video in Picture in Picture while they also use a different app.

content.description: Two iPhone screenshots displayed side by side showing iOS multitasking with Picture in Picture functionality. LEFT SCREENSHOT: Shows the iOS App Switcher interface with multiple app cards stacked in a 3D carousel view. Visible apps include what appears to be a Safari browser window and other applications. The status bar shows time and cellular/wifi indicators. At the bottom of the screen, there's a FaceTime Picture in Picture window showing a video call participant (person with long dark hair visible in a small rounded rectangle overlay). The home indicator bar is visible at the bottom. RIGHT SCREENSHOT: Shows a Notes app or similar application with a FaceTime Picture in Picture window floating in the upper right corner. The PiP window shows the same video call participant. The main app content shows a list or document view with text entries. The status bar and home indicator are also visible.
content.composition: Two iPhone device frames positioned side by side horizontally, showing different multitasking states
content.technicalDetails: iPhone running iOS, App Switcher view and standard app view with PiP overlay, portrait orientation
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates how iPhone users can continue FaceTime calls while using other apps through Picture in Picture
content.caption: The app switcher displays all currently open apps. A current FaceTime call can continue while people use another app.

content.text: The app switcher displays all currently open apps. A current FaceTime call can continue while people use another app.

paragraphs.text: On iPad, people can view and interact with the windows of several different apps at the same time. An individual app can also support multiple open windows, which lets people view and interact with more than one window in the same app at one time.

People can use iPad with either full-screen or windowed apps. When full screen, apps occupy the full screen, and people can switch between individual app windows using the app switcher. When using windowed apps, app windows are resizable, and people can arrange them to suit their needs with behavior similar to macOS. The system provides window controls for common tiling configurations, entering full screen, minimizing, and closing windows. The system identifies the frontmost window by coloring its window controls and casting a drop shadow on windows behind it. For guidance, see Windows > iPadOS.
Additionally, videos and FaceTime calls can also play in a Picture in Picture overlay above other content regardless of whether apps are full screen or windowed.

content.label: Note
content.text: Apps don't control multitasking configurations or receive any indication of the ones that people choose.

To help your app respond correctly when people open it while windowed, make sure it adapts gracefully to different screen sizes. For guidance, see Layout and Windows; for developer guidance, see Multitasking on iPad, Mac, and Apple Vision Pro. To learn more about how people use iPad multitasking features, see Use multitasking on your iPad.

links.text: Multitasking on iPad, Mac, and Apple Vision Pro

content.description: An iPad screenshot showing the windowed multitasking experience in iPadOS. The screen displays multiple overlapping application windows arranged on the desktop, similar to macOS. Multiple app windows are visible including what appears to be Safari, Notes, and other applications. Each window has standard window controls (traffic light buttons) in the top-left corner for close, minimize, and full-screen actions. The windows cast subtle drop shadows to indicate their layering order. The frontmost window has more prominent/colored window controls while background windows appear slightly dimmed. The iPad dock is visible at the bottom of the screen with various app icons. The desktop wallpaper is visible in the background areas not covered by windows.
content.composition: Multiple resizable windows overlapping in a desktop-like arrangement, demonstrating macOS-style window management on iPad
content.technicalDetails: iPad running iPadOS with Stage Manager or windowed mode enabled, landscape orientation
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the windowed multitasking experience on iPad where apps behave similarly to macOS with resizable, overlapping windows
content.caption: When using windowed apps, app windows are resizable, and people can arrange them to suit their needs with behavior similar to macOS. The system provides window controls for common tiling configurations, entering full screen, minimizing, and closing windows. The system identifies the frontmost window by coloring its window controls and casting a drop shadow on windows behind it.

paragraphs.text: On Mac, multitasking is the default experience because people typically run more than one app at a time, switching between windows and tasks as they work. When multiple app windows are open, macOS applies drop shadows that make the windows appear layered on the desktop, and applies other visual effects to help people distinguish different window states; for guidance, see macOS window states.
On Apple TV, people can play or browse content while also playing movies or TV shows in Picture in Picture (where supported).
On Apple Vision Pro, people can run multiple apps at the same time in the Shared Space, viewing and switching between windows and volumes throughout the space.

Only one window is active at a time in the Shared Space. When people look from one window to another, the window they're currently looking at becomes active while the previous window becomes more translucent and appears to recede along the z-axis. Closing an app window in the Shared Space transitions the app to the background without quitting it.

content.label: Note
content.text: When an app is the Now Playing app, closing its window automatically pauses audio playback; if people want to resume playback, they can do so in Control Center without opening the window.

items.leadText: Avoid interfering with the system-provided multitasking behavior.
items.bodyText: When people look from one window to another, visionOS applies a feathered mask to the window they look away from to clarify its changed state. To avoid interfering with this visual feedback, don't change the appearance of a window's edges.

items.leadText: Don't pause a window's video playback when people look away from it.
items.bodyText: In visionOS, as in macOS, people expect the playback they start in one window to continue while they view or perform a task in another window.
items.playIconDescription: A small gray play button icon (triangle pointing right) appears before this bullet point

items.leadText: Be prepared for situations where your audio can duck.
items.bodyText: Unless an app is currently the Now Playing app, its audio can duck when people look away from it to another app.

content.description: An illustration showing the visionOS video playback continuation behavior. The image shows a stylized representation of a video player window with a play button icon, along with visual indicators suggesting that playback continues when the user looks away. The design uses Apple's clean, minimal aesthetic with subtle gradients and shadows typical of visionOS interface elements.
content.composition: Centered diagram showing video playback persistence concept
content.technicalDetails: Conceptual illustration for visionOS multitasking behavior
content.contextualRelevance: Illustrates that video should continue playing when users look away from the window in visionOS
content.caption: Don't pause a window's video playback when people look away from it.

pages.pageSummary: This Apple Developer Documentation page provides comprehensive Human Interface Guidelines for implementing multitasking across Apple platforms. It covers best practices including pausing activities when switching apps, handling audio interruptions gracefully, completing background tasks, and using notifications sparingly. Platform-specific guidance is provided for iOS (Picture in Picture with FaceTime), iPadOS (full-screen and windowed modes with Stage Manager), macOS (default windowed experience), tvOS (Picture in Picture), and visionOS (Shared Space with gaze-based window activation). The page includes visual examples, notes about platform limitations, links to related documentation and WWDC videos, and a change log documenting updates since 2023.

keyTerms.definition: The ability to switch quickly from one app to another, performing tasks in each
A feature that allows video or FaceTime calls to play in a small overlay window while using other apps
System interface that displays all currently open apps for switching between them
The visionOS environment where multiple apps can run simultaneously with windows and volumes throughout the space
A visionOS mode where an app takes over the entire immersive experience, typically used by games
The app currently designated as the primary audio playback source in the system
Temporarily lowering audio volume when another audio source needs attention
System-provided buttons for tiling, full screen, minimizing, and closing windows
Visual effect applied to windows to indicate layering and the frontmost window
Visual effect in visionOS applied to inactive windows to clarify changed state

keyFindings: Every app needs to support multitasking with rare exceptions (some games, visionOS Full Space apps)
Apps must be prepared to save and restore context at any time since users can initiate multitasking unexpectedly
Audio should pause indefinitely for primary interruptions but only temporarily for short interruptions like GPS notifications
User-initiated tasks should complete in the background even when the user switches away
Notifications should be used sparingly - only for important or time-sensitive task completions
On iOS, FaceTime and videos can continue in Picture in Picture while using other apps
On iPadOS, apps can run in full-screen mode or windowed mode similar to macOS
Apps don't control multitasking configurations or receive indication of user choices
On macOS, multitasking is the default experience with drop shadows indicating window layering
On visionOS, only one window is active at a time based on gaze direction
In visionOS Shared Space, closing a window backgrounds the app without quitting it
visionOS applies a feathered mask to windows users look away from
Apps should not pause video playback when users look away in visionOS
Non-Now Playing app audio can duck when users look away in visionOS

ipadOSModes.fullScreen: Apps occupy full screen, switch via app switcher
ipadOSModes.windowed: Resizable windows, macOS-like behavior, system window controls

visionOSBehavior.activeWindow: Only one window active at a time
visionOSBehavior.inactiveWindows: Become more translucent, appear to recede along z-axis
visionOSBehavior.windowClosing: Transitions app to background without quitting
visionOSBehavior.audioPlayback: Now Playing app closing pauses audio, resumable via Control Center

audioHandling.shortInterruptions: Lower volume or pause temporarily, resume when done

designDecisions.decision: Apps must always be prepared to save and restore context
designDecisions.rationale: Users can initiate multitasking at any time unexpectedly

designDecisions.decision: Pause activities requiring attention when user switches away
designDecisions.rationale: Prevent users from missing content in games or media apps
Users expect downloads and processing to finish even after switching apps

designDecisions.decision: Use notifications sparingly for task completion
designDecisions.rationale: Only important/time-sensitive tasks warrant interrupting the user

designDecisions.decision: Don't interfere with visionOS feathered mask system feedback
designDecisions.rationale: System provides visual feedback for window state changes that should not be overridden

designDecisions.decision: Don't pause video when users look away in visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: Matches user expectation from macOS where playback continues in background windows

designDecisions.decision: Apps should adapt gracefully to different screen sizes
designDecisions.rationale: iPadOS windowed mode means apps can be opened at various sizes
